normalised: Understanding Childhood Immunization Schedules in India

unnormalised: Vaccinating children is a crucial step in ensuring their health and well-being. In India, the Government of India provides a Universal Immunization Programme (UIP) which offers free vaccines against several life-threatening diseases. Parents often have questions regarding the schedule, dosage, and importance of these vaccinations. This article aims to provide clarity on the standard immunization schedule for children in India, focusing particularly on the first 5 yrs of a child's life. It's important to note that some pvt. hospitals might recommend addl. vaccines not covered under the UIP.
normalised: Vaccinating children is a crucial step in ensuring their health and well-being. In India, the Government of India provides a Universal Immunization Programme (U-I-P) which offers free vaccines against several life-threatening diseases. Parents often have questions regarding the schedule, dosage, and importance of these vaccinations. This article aims to provide clarity on the standard immunization schedule for children in India, focusing particularly on the first five years of a child's life. It is important to note that some private hospitals might recommend additional vaccines not covered under the U-I-P.

unnormalised: At birth, newborns typically receive the BCG vaccine, which protects against tuberculosis (TB), and the first dose of the Oral Polio Vaccine (OPV). The Hepatitis B vaccine is also often administered at birth or within the first 24 hours. Parents should ensure they receive a vaccination card, which serves as a record of the vaccines administered and future appointments. The card will indicate the next set of vaccinations usually due at 6 wks.
normalised: At birth, newborns typically receive the B-C-G vaccine, which protects against tuberculosis (T-B), and the first dose of the Oral Polio Vaccine (O-P-V). The Hepatitis B vaccine is also often administered at birth or within the first twenty four hours. Parents should ensure they receive a vaccination card, which serves as a record of the vaccines administered and future appointments. The card will indicate the next set of vaccinations usually due at six weeks.

unnormalised: The 6-week mark is significant. At this age, babies receive the first doses of Pentavalent vaccine (DPT, Hib, HepB), Rota virus vaccine, and fractional Inactivated Polio Vaccine (fIPV). The Pentavalent vaccine protects against diphtheria, pertussis (whooping cough), tetanus, Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib), and Hepatitis B. These are crucial for preventing these diseases, which can be particularly dangerous for infants. It's common for babies to experience a mild fever after the DPT shot. Always consult with ur pediatrician at such times.
normalised: The six-week mark is significant. At this age, babies receive the first doses of Pentavalent vaccine (D-P-T, H-i-b, HepB), Rota virus vaccine, and fractional Inactivated Polio Vaccine (f-I-P-V). The Pentavalent vaccine protects against diphtheria, pertussis (whooping cough), tetanus, Haemophilus influenzae type b (H-i-b), and Hepatitis B. These are crucial for preventing these diseases, which can be particularly dangerous for infants. It is common for babies to experience a mild fever after the D-P-T shot. Always consult with your pediatrician at such times.

unnormalised: Subsequent doses of Pentavalent, Rota virus, and fIPV are administered at 10 wks and 14 wks. At 9 months, the child receives the Measles-Rubella (MR) vaccine and a dose of Vitamin A. This MR vaccine is critical in preventing measles and rubella, which can lead to severe complications. A booster dose of OPV is also administered. Don't forget to schedule appts in advance, many parents prefer doing it at 9 am.
normalised: Subsequent doses of Pentavalent, Rota virus, and f-I-P-V are administered at ten weeks and fourteen weeks. At nine months, the child receives the Measles-Rubella (M-R) vaccine and a dose of Vitamin A. This M-R vaccine is critical in preventing measles and rubella, which can lead to severe complications. A booster dose of O-P-V is also administered. Do not forget to schedule appointments in advance, many parents prefer doing it at nine A-M.

unnormalised: Between 16-24 months, the child receives the MR 2nd dose, DPT booster, and a dose of Vitamin A. These boosters are important to reinforce the immunity developed from the initial vaccines. It's also common to administer the Chickenpox vaccine around this time, though this is not part of the UIP and is usually administered by pvt. practitioners for approx. Rs. 2000 per dose. Parents should discuss the pros and cons of this vaccine with their doctor.
normalised: Between sixteen to twenty four months, the child receives the M-R second dose, D-P-T booster, and a dose of Vitamin A. These boosters are important to reinforce the immunity developed from the initial vaccines. It is also common to administer the Chickenpox vaccine around this time, though this is not part of the U-I-P and is usually administered by private practitioners for approximately rupee two thousand per dose. Parents should discuss the pros and cons of this vaccine with their doctor.

unnormalised: Staying informed about the immunization schedule and adhering to it diligently is a proactive step towards safeguarding your child's health. Always consult with a pediatrician or healthcare professional for personalized advice and to address any specific concerns. They can provide guidance on catch-up schedules if any vaccines are missed, and keep you informed about any updates to the national immunization program. Remember to keep that vaccine card safe; it's a really imp. document.
